awd_titl_txt: TWC: Medium: Collaborative: Long-term Active User Authentication Using Multi-modal Profiles
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims at advancing the state-of-the-art in cybersecurity by developing efficient methods for generating novel biometric signatures and performing active and continuous user authentication. Current authentication procedures typically occur once at the initial log-in stage and involve user proxies such as passwords and smart cards which suffer from several vulnerabilities. This research addresses these limitations by developing probabilistic, generative models to represent multimodal biometrics of every user in the system, so that any significant deviation from the user-specific model flags the presence of an imposter. This novel technique specifically targets mitigation of masquerading attacks which are particularly challenging to detect as they are mostly carried out by insiders familiar with the activity patterns of the authorized user.  The approach enables identification of intruders before they can hijack a user session of an authorized individual who may have momentarily stepped away from his/her console.

The project also involves extensive usability tests for seamless integration of the authentication processes in real-life computer and network systems, thus ensuring that data about the behavior and performance of people using the network is fed-back and incorporated into future designs of the security protocols. The methods also readily extend to protecting both wired and wireless networks, and mobile devices.

por.por_cntn:
The current standard methods of authenticating a computer user still primarily rely on using proxies such as user IDs and passwords, optionally complemented by other additional knowledge-based verification. Unfortunately, passwords can be lost, stolen, or phished; and data for knowledge-based authentication can be acquired through public posts, and in some cases, through large-scale data breaches. As a result, an unauthorized person can log into a victim’s account and gain access to important information. Recognized for many years as a problem, a 2016 report by the Commission on Enhancing National Cybersecurity indicated that “a review of the major breaches over the past six years reveals that compromised identity characteristics have consistently been the main point of entry.” Moreover, given the recent large-scale identity data breaches and insider-triggered leaks, these attacks can become massive and widespread and, thus, extremely dangerous. What is urgently needed is the ability to detect malicious users even after they have broken into legitimate accounts. This research aims to provide such protection mechanisms based on keystroke and mouse dynamics that will continuously authenticate a user even after he/she has logged in.

 

Intellectual Merit

One key contribution of this project is the collection of a dataset of 12.9 million keystrokes and 90 million mouse events, from more than 100 users, spanning a period of 2.5 years. What make this new dataset unique is that it is collected in completely uncontrolled settings, and the largest of its kind. Using this unique dataset, we have investigated the impact of sample sizes and data quality on authentication performance. In one study we estimate that keystroke dynamics authentication can detect 98% imposters based on an average of 2.5 minutes of typing. The dataset has been cleaned for privacy concerns and made ready for research sharing.

 

The second key contribution of this project is the development and evaluation of a novel keystroke authentication algorithm that is based on kernel density estimation (KDE). Using our own largest uncontrolled keystroke dataset as well as three other public datasets, which are controlled in one way or another, we benchmark the new KDE based algorithm and two other state-of-the-art keystroke dynamics algorithms. We find that (1) all three algorithms perform worse on the new dataset than the other three controlled ones, showing the unique value of our own uncontrolled dataset, and (2) the new KDE based algorithm performs noticeably better than the other two algorithms in authentication performance, hence representing the new state of the art.

 

Broader Impacts

This award has supported one PhD student through the completion of his dissertation. Six papers have been published and one more is currently under review. In addition, this award has funded 21 REU students during academic semesters and/or summers. Four of those REU students have published papers as co-authors and two more as co-authors on a paper that is currently under review. The REU students have made 21 oral and poster presentations at Clarkson University’s Spring/Fall research symposia.
